title: 2 Easy Ways to Scale Windows & Mac Screen to Fit a Monitor

steps.title: Right-click on the desktop of your PC and select Display settings.
steps.content: Right-click on the desktop of your PC and select Display settings . This will open the display menu.

steps.title: Select the monitor display you wish to adjust.
steps.content: Select the monitor display you wish to adjust. In the gray box at the top, click on the box representing your monitor screen. Click Identify to see which screen the selected box represents.

steps.title: Select a resolution.
steps.content: Select a resolution. Click on the drop-down under Display resolution and select an option. Your screen will automatically preview the change. Windows will make a recommendation based on your monitor. If the recommended option doesn't work, try selecting a different resolution. A higher resolution will fit more on your screen, but details will appear smaller. A lower resolution will fit less on your screen and will appear zoomed in and blurrier.

steps.title: Click Keep Changes.
steps.content: Click Keep Changes . If you don't like how the preview looks, click Revert to go back and try a new option [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source .

steps.title: Go to System Settings.
steps.content: Go to System Settings . This is found in the Apple menu. You can also click on the gray gear icon in the Dock. If you're on an older version of macOS, the option will say System Preferences instead.

steps.title: Click Displays.
steps.content: Click Displays . This option appears in the left-hand menu bar. Look for a blue icon with a white sun on it. In earlier versions of macOS, Displays has an icon of a monitor and is located in the main System Preferences window.

steps.title: Choose a resolution.
steps.content: Choose a resolution. Typically, the possible resolutions for your display will appear as a series of thumbnails beneath the icon of your monitor. Click the one that works best for you. [2] X Research source You may see options including Larger Text (lower resolution), Default , and More Space (higher resolution). A higher resolution will fit more on your screen, but details will appear smaller. A lower resolution will fit less on your screen and will appear zoomed in and blurrier. To display the resolutions as a list instead of a series of thumbnails, Ctrl-click one of the thumbnails and select Show List . From this view, you can also toggle on Show all resolutions to see additional options. In earlier versions of macOS, you can select Default for display to use the recommended resolution, or click Scaled to see and choose from other options.

steps.title: Click the maximize button to fit a window to a monitor.
steps.content: Click the maximize button to fit a window to a monitor. If you have a window on your computer (such as a browser window, word processor, photo app, etc.) that doesn't fit your monitor size, you can make it fit your monitor by clicking the maximize button in the top bar of your window. Windows: The maximize button looks like two squares overlapping each other, next to the X button that closes the window. Mac: The maximize button is the green button in the upper-left corner of the window.
